intro: Eleutherococcus gracilistylus f. koreanus, commonly known as Korean deer antler plant, is a rare and endangered species native to the mountainous regions of Korea. It is a member of the Araliaceae family and is characterized by its distinctive, compound leaves and small, yellowish-green flowers. The plant produces berries that are typically red or black when mature, and it thrives in cool, shaded environments. Due to habitat destruction and over-collection, it is critically endangered and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
